thoughts.content: It sounds like the user is considering hyperbolic geometry through coordinate transformations, where a line (y=1) divides the plane across two quadrants. In hyperbolic and polar geometry, mappings can warp planes differently: hyperbolic geometry often uses models like the Poincaré half-plane to show how spaces curve, altering distances as you move. Polar geometry, meanwhile, “unwraps” the plane into a 360-degree span. The transformation from two quadrants to one in hyperbolic geometry is akin to curving or mapping the space.

Okay, the user seems to be thinking about hyperbolic geometry through coordinate transformations. The horizontal line they mention (y=1) spans the entire plane, crossing quadrants. The idea about warping it to span one quadrant might reference how the Poincaré disk model maps the hyperbolic plane within the unit disk, where geodesics are arcs. For polar geometry, expanding a line to 360 degrees could refer to radial coordinates, mapping a line to full angular range. The user wants the standard explanation for these transformations in hyperbolic geometry.

The user seems to be considering how Euclidean geometry lines can be "warped" into different geometries. Hyperbolic geometry involves applying a non-Euclidean metric, which rescales distances differently as you approach the boundary, making lines appear infinite. Similarly, in spherical and polar geometries, lines can warp into great circles. The explanation would involve curvature and how distances behave in different geometries: Euclidean (curvature 0), spherical (+1), and hyperbolic (-1). These transformations are often visualized through models like the Poincaré disk or the upper half-plane.

The user seems to want the standard explanation for how hyperbolic geometry comes from "warping" lines, particularly horizontal ones, into different shapes. In spherical geometry, the Euclidean plane maps to a sphere via stereographic projection, wrapping the infinite line into a circle. Hyperbolic geometry, on the other hand, involves mapping the plane to a hyperboloid, and projecting it into the Poincaré disk. The warped line appears as an arc, with the boundary limiting the span. This geometry is described using constant curvature surfaces. Geodesics distort under these projections.

parts:
The picture you have in mind really is the one geometers use:  
all three constant-curvature planes – spherical ( +1 ), Euclidean ( 0 ) and hyperbolic ( –1 ) – can be displayed **in the ordinary Euclidean plane just by multiplying the Euclidean metric by a suitable scale-factor**.  
That scale–factor “warps’’ the horizontal and vertical directions differently, so a straight horizontal line in the Euclidean sense turns into something that, from the point of view of the new metric, occupies “less than half’’ (hyperbolic) or “more than half’’ (spherical) of the full 360 ° around you.

---

### 1 Start with the flat plane

Write the complex coordinate \(z=x+iy\) and give the plane its usual metric  

\[
ds_{0}^{2}=|dz|^{2}=dx^{2}+dy^{2}.
\]

With this metric a horizontal line \(y=c\) really does extend through *two* quadrants: it runs for ever to the left (\(x\to-\infty\)) and to the right (\(x\to+\infty\)).  

---

### 2 Introduce a position-dependent scale factor

Choose a smooth positive function \( \Omega(x,y) \) and declare that distances are now measured with  

\[
ds^{2}=\Omega(x,y)^{2}\,ds_{0}^{2}.
\]

Because we have only *rescaled* lengths, angles are preserved; the change is purely in how far you have to walk to cover a given Euclidean length.

| curvature \(K\) | convenient model | scale factor \( \Omega(x,y) \) | name of the model |
|-----------------|------------------|--------------------------------|-------------------|
| \(+1\) | stereographic image of a sphere | \(\displaystyle \frac{2}{1+x^{2}+y^{2}}\) | spherical / “polar’’ |
| \(0\) | – | 1 | Euclidean |
| \(-1\) | Poincaré upper half–plane | \(\displaystyle \frac1{y}\) | hyperbolic |

Those three choices give **constant Gauss curvature** \(K=+1,0,-1\) respectively.  
(The sphere or the two-sheeted hyperboloid themselves carry those curvatures; the formulas above are just their canonical projections onto the plane.)

---

### 3 What happens to a horizontal line?

Take the line \(y=c\) and ask how far it stretches in the new geometry.

*Euclidean.*  
\(ds=dx\); the integral \(\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}dx\) diverges: the line is infinitely long and occupies 180 ° of your visual field (two quadrants).

*Spherical.*  
\[
ds=\frac{2}{1+x^{2}+c^{2}}\;dx\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\text{length}=2\Bigl(\tan^{-1}x\Bigr)\Big|_{-\infty}^{\infty}=2\pi.
\]
The line has become a **closed geodesic of length \(2\pi\)** – a great-circle seen via stereographic projection.  Walking straight on brings you right back to where you started, so it “fills’’ the full 360 ° around you.

*Hyperbolic.*  
\[
ds=\frac{1}{c}\,dx\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\text{length}=\frac1c\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}dx=\infty,
\]
but notice the *visual* effect: in the Poincaré half-plane the boundary \(y=0\) is at **finite optical distance**, so the ideal endpoints of the line lie straight ahead of you – never behind.  Said another way, every horizontal line meets the ideal boundary in exactly *one* quadrant of your visual field.

(Vertical lines or semicircles orthogonal to the boundary are the **geodesics** of the hyperbolic metric; a horizontal Euclidean line at \(y=c\) is *not* a geodesic, but the “one-quadrant’’ intuition you noticed comes from how the ideal boundary shortens the visible angle.)

---

### 4 The conformal models tie everything together

A single complex-analytic recipe produces all three geometries:

\[
ds_{K}^{2}=\frac{4\,|dz|^{2}}{(1+K|z|^{2})^{2}}
\quad
\begin{cases}
K=+1 &\text{(sphere)}\\
K=0  &\text{(Euclidean)}\\
K=-1 &\text{(hyperbolic\ disk)}
\end{cases}
\]

* For \(K=+1\) one is looking at the sphere from its north pole (stereographic projection).  
  Straight lines become circles that close up after \(360^{\circ}\).

* For \(K=-1\) one is looking at the two-sheeted hyperboloid from the origin of  
  3-dimensional Minkowski space (projective or Poincaré projection).  
  Straight lines become Euclidean circles or diameters that meet the boundary of the disk twice; each end appears “straight ahead”, so the line spans only a single quadrant.

The qualitative rule is simple:

| curvature | what a straight line does when you walk on it |
|-----------|----------------------------------------------|
| \(+1\)    | bends back, closes on itself (angle > 180°)   |
| \(0\)     | stays straight, goes on for ever (angle = 180°) |
| \(-1\)    | keeps diverging, never closes (angle < 180°)  |

Your “one-quadrant vs two-quadrant vs full-circle’’ observation is exactly this constant-curvature trichotomy viewed through the conformal pictures we usually draw on a sheet of paper.

Be as mathematically and technically detailed as possible. Return a list of relevant papers with publication details and summaries of their contributions.

parts:
# Dynamical Systems under Small Perturbations: Theoretical Studies

## Noise-Induced Transitions and Nonequilibrium States

- **Ruelle (1981)** – *“Small Random Perturbations of Dynamical Systems and the Definition of Attractors.”* *Commun. Math. Phys.* **82**, 137 (1981). This foundational paper by David Ruelle re-examines the concept of attractors when a deterministic chaotic system is subjected to weak random perturbations. Ruelle proposes a new definition of attractors (inspired by Conley’s ideas) that aligns with what is observed under small stochastic perturbations【19†L43-L47】. In essence, the paper argues that the “strange attractors” seen in simulations and experiments (which always have some noise) correspond to measure-supported attractors under noisy dynamics. This work laid theoretical groundwork for understanding how invariant measures of chaotic systems are affected by infinitesimal noise.

- **van den Broeck, Parrondo & Toral (1994)** – *“Noise-Induced Nonequilibrium Phase Transition.”* *Phys. Rev. Lett.* **73**, 3395 (1994). This influential study demonstrated that **multiplicative (state-dependent) noise** can qualitatively change a system’s long-term behavior by inducing new stable states even when none exist deterministically. The authors used a stochastic model to show a genuine phase transition caused *solely by noise*: as the noise intensity passes a threshold, the system’s stationary probability distribution shifts from unimodal to bimodal (breaking symmetry despite the deterministic dynamics being monostable). This nonequilibrium steady-state has no analog in the noise-free system, highlighting how state-dependent fluctuations can drive a system into new **non-equilibrium steady states (NESS)**. The analysis was done via the Fokker–Planck equation and showed that detailed balance was broken, with a sustained probability current indicating a true NESS. This work is a cornerstone in **noise-induced transitions** theory, illustrating that noise can create or select new attractors (stable distributions) where deterministic dynamics had only one. (The general theory of such noise-induced phase transitions was further detailed in the monograph by Horsthemke & Lefever (1984), which provided a broader context for these phenomena.)

- **Landa & McClintock (2000)** – *“Changes in the Dynamical Behavior of Nonlinear Systems Induced by Noise.”* *Phys. Reports* **323**, 1–80 (2000). This is a comprehensive review that surveys how **weak noise can have far-reaching effects** on nonlinear dynamical systems. The authors demonstrate through many examples and theory that even very small random perturbations can cause qualitative changes such as transitions to new states or attractors that are inaccessible in the purely deterministic system【18†L1-L8】. Topics covered include noise-induced transitions, stochastic resonance, and noise-modified bifurcations. Mathematically, they discuss the use of stochastic differential equations and their associated Fokker–Planck formulations to compute stationary distributions and transition rates. A key insight is that multistable systems under small noise exhibit *metastability*: the system can hop between attractors, with noise determining the residence times (Kramers’ escape rate theory is reviewed). This report solidified understanding that *noise is not merely a nuisance* but can fundamentally alter dynamical behavior, creating **new effective attractors or steady states** and even inducing chaos in some cases. It provided a unifying framework for phenomena like **noise-induced order** and **chaos stabilization/destruction by noise**, citing both theoretical results and consistent observations across physical and biological systems【18†L1-L8】.

- **Kraut, Feudel & Grebogi (1999)** – *“Preference of Attractors in Noisy Multistable Systems.”* *Phys. Rev. E* **59**, 5253 (1999). This paper examines how a multistable deterministic system (one with several coexisting attractors) behaves under the influence of weak noise. Counterintuitively, the presence of noise can cause the system to **prefer** one attractor over others, even if all attractors are equally stable in the deterministic sense. The authors use a combination of simulation and Fokker–Planck analysis to show that asymmetric probabilities of visiting each attractor arise from differences in basin geometry and the structure of invariant manifolds. Essentially, small random perturbations break the neutral “selection” of coexisting attractors and bias the stationary occupancy towards one attractor (often the one with the largest basin or with a nearby chaotic saddle). This work is theoretical but has implications for any noisy multistable system: it explains why one outcome may dominate in practice. It also highlights that a system’s **invariant measure** under noise is concentrated around one attractor more than others, illustrating an information-theoretic idea that noise “picks” the most accessible attractor. This study complements earlier results by providing quantitative measures of attractor preference and showing how to compute the stationary distribution over states in a multistable landscape via the FP equation.

- **Kraut & Feudel (2002)** – *“Multistability, Noise, and Attractor Hopping: The Crucial Role of Chaotic Saddles.”* *Phys. Rev. E* **66**, 015207(R) (2002). Here, the authors delve into **noise-driven transitions** (“hopping”) between attractors in a chaotic multistable system and discover that the mechanism hinges on *chaotic saddle* structures. By applying symbolic dynamics and numerical analysis, they found a sudden increase in dynamical entropy (randomness of trajectories) as a control parameter is varied under fixed noise【35†L66-L74】. This was explained by a novel bifurcation involving two chaotic saddles – essentially, noise allows trajectories to escape an attractor by briefly visiting an unstable chaotic saddle in the basin boundary, leading to a hop into a different attractor. They quantified how the **transient lifetimes** on these saddles follow a scaling law akin to the crisis-induced intermittency in chaos theory. The paper uses a Fokker–Planck operator perturbative approach to estimate transition rates between attractors. The key contribution is the identification of a *geometric mechanism* for noise-induced attractor hopping: the presence of a chaotic saddle in phase space acts as a gateway for noise to push the system from one basin to another. This deepens the theoretical understanding of **noisy chaotic systems**, showing that even in fully chaotic regimes, small perturbations (noise) can exploit underlying saddle sets to produce qualitatively new behavior (intermittency, random hops). It bridges deterministic chaos theory with stochastic analysis by linking crisis bifurcations and FP escape-rate calculations.

- **Forgoston & Moore (2018)** – *“A Primer on Noise-Induced Transitions in Applied Dynamical Systems.”* *SIAM Review* **60**(4), 969–1009 (2018). This article is a modern tutorial-style review that synthesizes the theory of **rare events and transitions in stochastic dynamical systems**. It is highly relevant as it emphasizes that even **weak noise can induce large changes** in system behavior, such as escapes from a quasi-stable state or switches between metastable attractors【23†L65-L73】. The authors outline the mathematics of stochastic processes (using SDEs with state-dependent noise), the Fokker–Planck equation for evolving probability densities, and especially the **Wentzell–Freidlin large deviation theory** for estimating transition paths and rates. They discuss how to compute **quasi-potential landscapes** for non-gradient systems, which generalize the notion of an energy landscape in nonequilibrium settings. Non-equilibrium steady states (NESS) are highlighted in the context of probability currents: the primer shows how detailed balance is broken in systems with state-dependent perturbations and how that leads to persistent probability fluxes in steady state. The review also connects to information theory by discussing entropy-like Lyapunov functions for the FP equation (e.g. relative entropy decay). Overall, this primer provides a technically detailed yet accessible summary of how small random perturbations produce *tipping events* in dynamical systems, with methods to analyze these events (action minimization, FP eigenfunctions, etc.). It solidifies concepts with examples, making it clear how **noise both creates and destroys attractors** in a controlled fashion【23†L65-L73】.

## Controlling Chaos and Multistability with Small Perturbations

- **Pisarchik & Feudel (2014)** – *“Control of Multistability.”* *Physics Reports* **540**, 167–218 (2014). This is an extensive theoretical review of methods to control multistable dynamical systems, i.e. systems with coexisting attractors. A major theme is the use of **small perturbations as control signals** to navigate between different attractors or eliminate undesired ones. The paper covers both feedback and non-feedback (open-loop) control strategies. Notably, it discusses *weak periodic or stochastic perturbations* that can destabilize certain attractors and drive the system into a desired state. For example, applying carefully timed small kicks or noise pulses can induce *attractor switching*. The authors point out that multistable systems are **extremely sensitive to tiny perturbations**, which is a challenge but also an opportunity for control【27†L37-L40】【27†L19-L27】. They review techniques like short pulses for attractor selection, harmonic perturbations to annihilate specific attractors, and noise-induced switching for favoring a desired attractor (sometimes called “stochastic control”). The article also surveys theoretical tools – including Fokker–Planck descriptions for stochastic perturbations – to predict the outcome of a control intervention. A key insight is that because each attractor corresponds to a distinct system performance, being able to induce transitions with minimal perturbation energy has high value. This work is **purely theoretical** (though motivated by applications) and consolidates knowledge on how **tiny controls can achieve large changes** in a system’s long-term behavior. It emphasizes that any small external perturbation (even incidental noise) may switch the system from one attractor to another, fundamentally changing the dynamics【27†L19-L27】. Controlling multistability is thus presented as a feasible task by exploiting the inherent sensitivity of nonlinear systems.

- **Ott, Grebogi & Yorke (1990)** – *“Controlling Chaos.”* *Phys. Rev. Lett.* **64**, 1196 (1990). Although not focused on stochastic noise, this classic theoretical paper introduced the idea that a chaotic system’s behavior can be controlled and stabilized onto a desired trajectory by the application of arbitrarily small perturbations. The OGY method treats slight parameter variations or tiny kicks as control signals that leverage the system’s natural dynamics to guide it to an existing unstable periodic orbit (a new attractor in practical terms). The relevance here is conceptual: it showed that **dissipative chaotic systems** can be tamed with minimal intervention, highlighting the extreme sensitivity to initial conditions and parameters as a tool rather than a hindrance. The method relies on linearizing the Poincaré map near the target orbit and making minute adjustments when the trajectory passes close by. OGY’s success sparked a whole subfield of chaos control. While it does not involve SDEs or Fokker–Planck equations, it is a theoretical cornerstone in treating *perturbations as control signals* in dynamical systems. The paper demonstrated that a chaotic attractor can be converted into a regular (periodic) attractor by **tiny deterministic perturbations**, thereby changing the system’s qualitative dynamics with virtually no energy cost. This result complements stochastic approaches by suggesting that even in the absence of noise, one can impose small controlled perturbations to achieve a similar effect – driving the system to a different attractor (e.g. stabilizing an otherwise unreachable steady state or cycle). OGY is a purely theoretical development with profound implications for how we understand stability and control in nonlinear systems.

*(**Note:** The Ott–Grebogi–Yorke method above is deterministic; it’s included here to illustrate the concept of small control perturbations in chaos. The rest of the listed works focus on stochastic perturbations and Fokker–Planck analysis.)*

## Fokker–Planck in Information-Theoretic and Control Contexts

- **Wibisono, Jog & Loh (2017)** – *“Information and Estimation in Fokker–Planck Channels.”* (Proc. IEEE ISIT 2017; arXiv:1702.03656). This theoretical paper recasts a general stochastic dynamical system as an information-theoretic communication channel (the “Fokker–Planck channel”). The authors consider a state-dependent SDE $dX_t = a(X_t)dt + \sigma(X_t)dW_t$ and derive how **entropy** and **information measures** evolve in time according to the Fokker–Planck equation governing $p(x,t)$. They show that the time-derivatives of Shannon entropy, Kullback–Leibler divergence, and mutual information for the state distribution can be *exactly expressed* in terms of generalized Fisher information metrics【32†L1-L4】. This extends classical information identities (De Bruijn’s identity and the I-MMSE relation) to the case of state-dependent diffusion (multiplicative noise). One key result is that while entropy itself need not increase monotonically in such processes, the relative entropy between two solutions of the FP equation decays at a rate given by a “relative Fisher information”【32†L49-L57】【32†L61-L69】. In practical terms, this means any **perturbation** that steers the system’s distribution (thought of as a control signal) can be linked to an information cost (via Fisher info), and the Fokker–Planck framework provides a rigorous way to quantify the “information flow” in the dynamics. Though not about attractors per se, this work is valuable in an **information-theoretic view of nonequilibrium systems**, particularly highlighting how state-dependent noise influences entropy and information transfer. It merges stochastic control intuition with estimation theory, indicating how small control perturbations might be optimally designed by looking at information gain or dissipation in the Fokker–Planck evolution【32†L1-L4】.

- **Annunziato & Borzì (2018)** – *“A Fokker–Planck Control Framework for Stochastic Systems.”* *EMS Surveys in Math. Sciences* **5**(1), 65–98 (2018). This article presents a formal framework for **optimal control of the probability density** of stochastic dynamical systems using the Fokker–Planck equation. Instead of controlling individual trajectories, the goal is to design a control input (a small perturbing force or parameter variation) that steers the whole probability distribution $p(x,t)$ to a desired target distribution or along a desired evolution. The authors formulate the control problem as an optimization problem with the FP equation as a constraint. They show that many stochastic control problems can be recast as **deterministic PDE control** problems on the FP equation【21†L5-L13】【21†L19-L27】. Under small control signals, linearization is possible and the connection to the Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman (HJB) equation of classical control is elucidated – in fact, they prove an equivalence between this FP control approach and the HJB dynamic programming approach under certain assumptions【21†L19-L27】. Technically, they handle cases of state-dependent diffusion (including fractional diffusion and jump processes), thus encompassing a wide range of SDEs. The paper is rich in mathematical detail: it derives gradient formulas for the control of the FP equation and discusses numerical methods. For the context of this query, the significance is that it treats *perturbations explicitly as control signals* applied to SDEs and uses the Fokker–Planck formalism to predict how those signals drive the system into new steady distributions or transient behaviors. It’s a purely theoretical development that bridges stochastic dynamics with control theory, reinforcing that **small inputs can be designed to produce big changes** in the system’s probabilistic behavior by exploiting the FP dynamics【21†L5-L13】.

- **Kappen (2005)** – *“Path Integrals and Symmetry Breaking for Optimal Control Theory.”* *Phys. Rev. Lett.* **95**, 200201 (2005). In this theoretical paper, H.J. Kappen reformulates certain nonlinear stochastic optimal control problems as path integrals, linking them to statistical mechanics. While the focus is on solving control problems, one notable finding is the existence of a **critical noise intensity** above which the structure of the optimal control solution qualitatively changes (a form of symmetry breaking in the control cost landscape). This hints that small vs. large perturbation regimes can lead to fundamentally different dynamical outcomes – effectively, noise can *assist* control. The path-integral approach leads to a **linear Fokker–Planck equation** (or Schrödinger-type equation) for the controlled probability density, making the control problem analytically tractable. For example, controlling a double-well system to switch wells is easier when a moderate amount of noise is present, as the noise helps overcome the barrier (an insight consistent with noise-induced transition theory). Kappen’s work, though framed in terms of optimal control, provides another perspective on how **stochastic perturbations** can be harnessed to drive systems between attractors. It shows that introducing or increasing noise can *lower the control effort* needed to reach a new attractor (since noise itself provides energy to escape basins), a concept with parallels in the idea of “stochastic resonance” and “noise-enabled control.” This paper is entirely theoretical and contributes to the information-theoretic understanding of controlled diffusions by showing how control objectives can be met by tuning noise and using FP path-integral solutions, rather than fighting against noise.

## Recent Advances with State-Dependent Noise

- **Phillips, Lindner & Kantz (2025)** – *“Stabilizing Role of Multiplicative Noise in Nonconfining Potentials.”* *Phys. Rev. Research* **7**, 023146 (2025). This very recent theoretical work examines a striking effect: adding *parametric noise* (noise whose intensity depends on state) to a system that lacks a confining potential can actually induce **stability and new steady states**. The authors develop a perturbative framework (using scale parameter expansions) for SDEs with multiplicative noise and show that increasing the noise intensity causes the stationary probability distribution to concentrate around certain state values (specifically, the minima of the noise coefficient function)【44†L45-L53】. In other words, the noise itself creates effective “potential wells” that were absent in the deterministic system, thus **stabilizing the dynamics around new attractors**. However, due to the stochasticity, the system also exhibits burst-like intermittent jumps between these noise-created attractors (when multiple minima exist), akin to on-off intermittency if one of the minima corresponds to a zero noise amplitude【44†L49-L57】. The paper uses the Fokker–Planck equation to quantify the stationary distribution’s shape (introducing measures like full-width-half-maximum since mean and variance may be infinite for heavy-tailed cases). One practical example discussed is a particle in a *flat* or double-well potential: without noise it might drift unbounded or wander, but multiplicative noise can pin the particle around certain locations and produce a quasistationary distribution. This counterintuitive **noise-induced stabilization** is deeply theoretical; it highlights how state-dependent perturbations can give rise to **non-equilibrium steady states** where entropy production does not vanish (a hallmark of NESS). The results connect to tipping-point analysis in climate and other fields by suggesting that noise could prevent a system from tipping by creating a temporary stabilizing basin. This study underscores that small stochastic perturbations, if of the right form, can fundamentally alter the phase-space structure of a system, imposing new attractors where none existed deterministically【44†L45-L53】【44†L49-L57】.

- **Abril-Bermúdez *et al.* (2025)** – *“Path Integral for Multiplicative Noise: Generalized Fokker–Planck Equation and Entropy Production Rate in Stochastic Processes with Threshold.”* *Phys. Rev. Research* **7**, 023185 (2025). This advanced theoretical paper extends the path-integral formalism for SDEs with arbitrary state-dependent noise, addressing mathematical subtleties in defining path integrals for multiplicative noise. By carefully treating the Jacobian (using a Parisi–Sourlas approach) and incorporating a cumulant-generating functional for the noise, the authors derive a **generalized Fokker–Planck equation** that remains valid even when standard FP equations would involve higher-order derivatives or ambiguity. They then apply the formalism to examples like Brownian motion with reflecting thresholds and geometric Brownian motion, computing analytical expressions for the **probability density, Shannon entropy, and entropy production rate** in the stationary state【38†L139-L147】【38†L144-L152】. One notable result is that for processes like restricted (bounded) Brownian motion or geometric Brownian motion, a true equilibrium (with zero entropy production) is never reached – instead these systems settle into a **quasi-steady state** with ongoing entropy production【38†L144-L152】. This indicates a NESS maintained by the multiplicative noise. The paper thus links **information-theoretic quantities** (entropy and its production) with the Fokker–Planck description of state-dependent noisy dynamics. It provides a rigorous way to calculate how small perturbations (especially those with thresholds or state-dependent switching) drive the system away from equilibrium. In summary, Abril-Bermúdez *et al.* give a cutting-edge theoretical toolkit for analyzing SDEs with multiplicative noise, and they show explicitly how such noise can generate complex steady-state behavior accompanied by continuous information/entropy flow in the system. This contributes to both the mathematical theory of FP equations and the physical understanding of **how state-dependent fluctuations create and sustain nonequilibrium steady states**【38†L139-L147】【38†L144-L152】.

Each of the above papers provides a **theoretical insight** into how small perturbations (modeled as noise or control inputs) can dramatically influence dynamical systems. They collectively cover the emergence of new attractors or steady distributions due to noise, methods to control or exploit these perturbations, and the use of the Fokker–Planck formalism (often coupled with information theory) to analyze the effects. All results are obtained analytically or through mathematical analysis of models, emphasizing general principles rather than specific experimental systems. The unifying theme is that **tiny inputs can produce qualitative changes** in system behavior, whether by inducing transitions between existing attractors, creating new effective attractors, or optimizing certain behaviors, and the Fokker–Planck equation is a crucial tool in quantifying these changes.

metadata.title: Small random perturbations of dynamical systems and the definition of attractors | Communications in Mathematical Physics
metadata.text: The “strange attractors” plotted by computers and seen in physical experiments do not necessarily have an open basin of attraction. In view of this we study a new definition of attractors based on ideas of Conley. We argue that the attractors observed in the presence of small random perturbations correspond to this new definition.

metadata.title: [nlin/0309015] Multistability, noise and attractor-hopping: The crucial role of chaotic saddles
metadata.text: > Abstract: We investigate the hopping dynamics between different attractors in a multistable system under the influence of noise. Using symbolic dynamics we find a sudden increase of dynamical entropies, when a system parameter is varied. This effect is explained by a novel bifurcation involving two chaotic saddles. We also demonstrate that the transient lifetimes on the saddle obey a scaling law in analogy to crisis.

metadata.title: [1712.03785] A primer on noise-induced transitions in applied dynamical systems
metadata.text: > Abstract:Noise plays a fundamental role in a wide variety of physical and biological dynamical systems. It can arise from an external forcing or due to random dynamics internal to the system. It is well established that even weak noise can result in large behavioral changes such as transitions between or escapes from quasi-stable states. These transitions can correspond to critical events such as failures or extinctions that make them essential phenomena to understand and quantify, despite the fact that their occurrence is rare. This article will provide an overview of the theory underlying the dynamics of rare events for stochastic models along with some example applications.

Abstract. A new framework for the optimal control of probability density functions (PDF) of stochastic processes is reviewed. This framework is based on Fokker-Planck (FP) partial differential equations that govern the time evolution of the PDF of stochastic systems and on control objectives that may require to follow a given PDF trajectory or to minimize an expectation functional. Corresponding to different stochastic processes, different FP equations are

The connection between the Dynamic Programming scheme given by the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equation and the FP control framework is discussed. Under appropriate assumptions, it is shown that the two strategies are equivalent. Some applications of the FP control framework to different models are discussed and its extension in a mean-field framework is elucidated. This is a preprint of the paper Mario Annunziato and Alfio Borzì

metadata.title: The stabilizing role of multiplicative noise in non-confining potentials
metadata.text: We provide a simple framework for the study of parametric (multiplicative) noise, making use of scale parameters. We show that for a large class of stochastic differential equations increasing the multiplicative noise intensity surprisingly causes the mass of the stationary probability distribution to become increasingly concentrated around the minima of the multiplicative noise term, whilst under quite general conditions exhibiting a kind of intermittent burst like jumps between these minima. If the multiplicative noise term has one zero this causes on-off intermittency. Our framework relies on first term expansions, which become more accurate for larger noise intensities. In this

content_references.title: Small random perturbations of dynamical systems and the definition of attractors | Communications in Mathematical Physics
content_references.snippet: The “strange attractors” plotted by computers and seen in physical experiments do not necessarily have an open basin of attraction. In view of this we study a new definition of attractors based on ideas of Conley. We argue that the attractors observed in the presence of small random perturbations correspond to this new definition.

content_references.title: [nlin/0309015] Multistability, noise and attractor-hopping: The crucial role of chaotic saddles
content_references.snippet: > Abstract: We investigate the hopping dynamics between different attractors in a multistable system under the influence of noise. Using symbolic dynamics we find a sudden increase of dynamical entropies, when a system parameter is varied. This effect is explained by a novel bifurcation involving two chaotic saddles. We also demonstrate that the transient lifetimes on the saddle obey a scaling law in analogy to crisis.

content_references.title: [1712.03785] A primer on noise-induced transitions in applied dynamical systems
content_references.snippet: > Abstract:Noise plays a fundamental role in a wide variety of physical and biological dynamical systems. It can arise from an external forcing or due to random dynamics internal to the system. It is well established that even weak noise can result in large behavioral changes such as transitions between or escapes from quasi-stable states. These transitions can correspond to critical events such as failures or extinctions that make them essential phenomena to understand and quantify, despite the fact that their occurrence is rare. This article will provide an overview of the theory underlying the dynamics of rare events for stochastic models along with some example applications.
